Freezers at the facility operate at 0?F or below.  The facility has approximately 54 dock doors to aid in the transportation of products.  In order to maintain freezer and cooling conditions, anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant.  The refrigeration system is a closed loop industrial refrigeration system. The ammonia is not used or mixed in any manner with other chemical processes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
LOS ANGELES COLD STORAGE COMPANY
RISK MANAGEMENT SUBMITTAL
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
CALIFORNIA ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

Los Angeles Cold Storage is a public refrigerated warehouse. The facility maintains a freezer area of 6.5 million cubic ft. which is used to store perishable products.  Freezers at the facility operate at 0?F or below.  The facility has approximately 54 dock doors to aid in the transportation of products.  In order to maintain freezer and cooling conditions, anhydrous ammonia is used as a refrigerant.  The refrigeration system is a closed loop industrial refrigeration system. The ammonia is not used or mixed in any manner with other chemical processes.

FACILITY CONSTRUCTION: The facility was designed and constructed in accordance with various Mechanical Building Codes depending on the timing.  These codes and guidelines outline requirements for the safe operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.

SAFETY FEATURES:  The ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Safeties include but are not limited to pressure relief valves, stop valves, ammonia detectors, and computerized refrigeration monitoring system as well as trained and experience operators.  Much of the safety associated with the system is also inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  For example, the facility operates in accordance with OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119) and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP, 40 CFR Part 68), as well as California?s Accidental Release Prevention Program (Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5).  

MANAGEMENT?S COMMITMENT TO SAFETY:  Management takes safety very seriously and mandates that the facility maintain a safe working environment for employees, community and products at all times.  Employees are trained on all safety issues relative to their duties and tasks and made aware of all required regulated safety

programs.  

A Safety Committee has also been established at the facility.  Committee members are hourly employees, supervisors and/or management. The primary responsibility of the Safety Committee is to meet, discuss and address safety issues.  The Committee also may conduct a safety walk-through at various times to look for possible unsafe conditions or procedures that may exist in and around the facility.  

Management also provides the necessary resources, monetary or with the proper personnel, to ensure that all elements within the regulations are adhered to.

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM:  A Management System has been developed and implemented to ensure that each element within PSM, RMP and CalARP regulations are properly addressed.  Each person is assigned components and is expected to aid in the development and implementation of the components as a whole.  The group works as a team to ensure that not only all elements are met but also to ensure that:  (1) Employees participate in the development and implementation of the programs (2) Aid in gathering Process Safety Information, (3) Operating procedures are developed and certified annually, (4) Safe Work practices are enforced, (5) the proper personnel serve as members of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and the all recommendations from the PHA are addressed in a timely manner,  (6)  Affected employees are properly trained as well as those whose jobs are working on or near the refrigeration system are appropriately trained, (7) Contractors are qualified to work on or near the refrigeration system and are informed on potential health risks associated with the system,  (8) Hot Work Permits are properly filled out and all persons affected by the work are aware of potential hazards, (9) Compliance Audits are performed and recommendations from the audits are assigned to proper personnel, and are addressed in a timely manner., (10)  Management of Change and Pre-Startup Safety Reviews are filled out and reviewed prior to con

ducting the change and placing ammonia into the system, (11)  All employees are trained on all elements of the Emergency Action Plan and that the plan is reviewed and certified at least annually, (12) Mechanical Integrity Inspections and tests are performed to ensure that the ammonia equipment is properly operating.  All deficiencies are noted and addressed in a timely manner.  (13) Incident Investigations are performed on accidental ammonia releases as well as near-misses.  Investigations are utilized to improve employee actions during an emergency. 

FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:  There have been no reportable ammonia related accidents, incidents or releases at the facility during 2003 thru submission date April - 2008.  

EMERGENCY ACTION PROGRAM:  The facility has established an Emergency Action Plan pursuant to CalOSHA, CCR Title 8, Section 3220 and 29CFR 1910.38. The Plan explains actions employees, contractor employees, and visitors take in the event of an emergency which include steps to take in the event of a fire, earthquake, tornado, ammonia release, etc. 
The Emergency Action Plan states that all employees shall: 
1)    Notify a supervisor or main office personnel to begin the facility evacuation steps and set in motion the public announce (PA) system,
2)    Notify the appropriate emergency responders, 
3)    Notify and aid (if possible) other employees at the site, contractors or visitors of emergency as they evacuate the building, 
4)    Assist in a safe and orderly evacuation, 
5)    Gather and remain at the designated assembly area(s) for a head count.  
6)    Remain at the assembly area until a Supervisor instructs otherwise.  

The Emergency Action Plan is reviewed and updated at least once per year. 

PREVENTION PROGRAM 3:  
1. Employee Participation:  Employees such as the Chief Engineer, Assistant Engineer, Engineering Supervisors and Management are actively involved in the development and implementation of PSM and RMP programs.  Employees aid in gathering Process

Safety Information, development and implementation of Operating Procedures, are members of the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), aiding in the completion of recommendations from both PHA and Compliance Audits, screening process for hiring Contractors, 

2. Process Safety Information: Piping and Instrumentation Diagrams (P&ID) have been developed where all major components of the ammonia refrigeration system and all piping have been assigned a number. Information has been gathered to enable employees to identify and understand the potential hazards of the system. The written information includes the Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia.

3. Process Hazard Analysis: A formal study of the ammonia refrigeration system with management, safety, and maintenance personnel was conducted using the HAZOP method to evaluate the potential hazards of the system. 

4. Operating Procedures: Written standard operating procedures have been developed and are developed as needed for the ammonia refrigeration system to ensure safe operation of the system.  Each SOP is reviewed and certified by the Chief Engineer annually and as needed.  

5. Training: All ammonia refrigeration maintenance employees, Chief Engineers and Assistant Engineers are trained on all aspects of the ammonia system.  Each Engineer is encouraged to attend various types of training relative to the ammonia system and/or their respective position.    

6. Contractors: Contractors are screened and evaluated prior to performing work-on or near the ammonia refrigeration system.

7. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR):  A PSSR includes policy and procedures as well as a checklist to ensure that all documents relating to the PSSR are collected, reviewed and retained.   

8. Mechanical Integrity: A Mechanical Integrity policy and procedures has been implemented at this facility.  Mechanical Integrity Inspections are performed annually.  Engineers also conduct daily walk-through, log sheets, Preventative maintena

nce work orders, Vibration analysis, Oil analysis, etc.  

9. Hot Work Permits: A Hot Work Permit program is in place at this facility which requires Hot Work Permit?s to be completed prior to working on or near the process. 

10. Management of Change (MOC):  A MOC system is implemented.  MOCs are planned, tracked, and reviewed using Management of Change procedures and forms. 

11. Incident Investigation: All incidents and near-misses are investigated, reviewed, and documented using an incident investigation form.  Deficiencies are noted in the de-briefing and are addressed in a timely manner.

12. Emergency Planning and Response: The facility does not respond to ammonia releases, therefore they do not have an Emergency Response Plan

13. Compliance Audits: Audits are conducted every three years to ensure that all elements within the scope of PSM, RMP and CalARP are adhered to.  

14. Five-Year Accident History:  No ammonia related incidents have occurred at this facility in the past five years.  

15. Description of plans to improve safety:  Improve Preventative Maintenance documentation for all material handling equipment, continued employee safety meetings, continued training for the Refrigeration Operators.  

Worst Case Scenario
The total ammonia charge at Los Angeles Cold Storage consists of approximately 22,000 lbs.  The Low Temperature Pump Receiver (LTPR) is the largest vessel in the system; however the facility has a Standard Operating Procedure (SOP-Isolation and Pump Down of LPTR-1-located in the System Entire-Refrigeration SOPs/Isolation and Pump down of LPTR-1) which demonstrates that the facility DOES NOT pump down to this vessel.  Therefore, during a system pump down the High Pressure Receiver is used.  The High Pressure Receiver has a capacity of approximately 8,900 lbs at 80% of anhydrous ammonia.  Thus the maximum capacity of the High Pressure Receiver at 80% full of anhydrous ammonia was used in the Worst Case Scenario resulting in a release of 0

.9 miles.   

Alternative Case Scenario
Los Angeles Cold Storage considered the following alternative release scenarios for anhydrous ammonia and selected a scenario that was more likely to occur than the worst-case scenario and that would reach an endpoint offsite.  A minimum of five years accident history was considered during the Alternative Case Scenarios.  *NOTE: LACS has not had a reportable release of anhydrous ammonia within the past five years. 


Release Scenarios Considered: 
1.    Transfer hose release due to split or sudden hose uncoupling, 
2.    Process piping release from failure at flanges, joints, welds, valves and valve seals, and drains or bleeds. 
3.    Process vessel or pump release due to cracks, seal failure, or drain, bleed, or plug failure. 
4.    Vessel overfilling and spill, or over-pressurization and venting through relief valves or rupture disks.  

After much consideration and review of all Alternative Scenarios listed above, LACS chose an ammonia release from failure of valve seal as the most likely Alternative Scenario to occur and/or reach a Toxic Endpoint receptor.  The estimated distance to Toxic Endpoint is 0.1 miles.  According to Region I LEPCs Implementation Guidance Document, Section 4.4 Estimating Off-Site Receptors part (B) paragraph 2, LACS will report 0.5 miles as the distance to Toxic Endpoint rather than the 0.1 mile as EPA?s RMP Comp modeling program calculated.  

All sensitive receptors have been identified and placed on the Alternative Scenario Map within a 0.5 mile radius from LACS.  A document showing all Sensitive Receptors, addresses, phone numbers and (as requested by Anna Olekszyk, Hazardous Materials Programs, LAFD) the estimated occupation population within this radius is included in the RMP Submittal for the LAFD.  

Is LA Cold Storage Subject to: 
 Y   CalOSHA, CCR Title 8, Section 3220: Emergency Action Plan.
 N   CalOSHA, CCR Title 8, Section 5192: Hazardous Operation and Emergency Response.
 Y   CCR Title 14, Secti

on 815.01-820.01: Spill Prevention Program.
 N   RCRA ( 40 CFR 264, 265, 279.52)  Resource Conservation and Recovery      Act permitting requirements for solid waste.
 N   OPA-90 ( 40 CFR 113, 33 CFR 154, 49 CFR 194, 30 CFR 254)OES, Oil Pollution Act of 1990.
 Y   CCR Title 19, Section 2729-2732 Hazardous Materials Release Response Plans and Inventory, Business Plan.

EXTERNAL EVENTS/SEISMIC SUMMARY:  External events were considered during the Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) HAZOP as any type of catastrophic failure that could result in a line break.  Catastrophic failures are caused by (but not limited to): vehicular accident, meteorite impact, missile impact, sabotage, war, and seismic activity.  A table was used during the HAZOP and is available at the facility.  A table is also included in the RMP Submittal provided to Anna Olekszyk, Hazardous Materials Programs, LAFD, Los Angeles California.
